reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s operational definition of “SIE” (>=5 OOM increase in effective training compute in <1 year without more hardware) and argues this shifts attention from the mechanism (runaway acceleration despite compute bottlenecks) to an output proxy (algorithmic efficiency), potentially muddling the crux. This is moderately central because it bears directly on the headline probability claim and what would count as success/failure, but it doesn’t directly refute the core object-level case about CES/ρ and compute bottlenecks. The critique has some bite (definitions can obscure acceleration dynamics), but it overreaches by implying the definition makes the claim ‘nearly unfalsifiable’ or that ‘any’ algorithmic progress would qualify—whereas the threshold (5 OOM in <1 year) is extremely strong and still clearly falsifiable. Thus, moderate correctness and limited refutational strength. It is clearly written, focused on a single issue, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Defining SIE by output metrics rather than acceleration makes the claim unfalsifiable
